alert.note: Alert for Big Horn; Carbon; Park; Stillwater; Sweet Grass; Wheatland (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 11 at 12:13PM MDT by NWS Billings
info.description: ...Foothills flooding possible due to rapid snowmelt... With recent warm temperatures, expect continuing increased snowmelt over area foothills. Between 5000 feet and 7000 feet snowpack is currently near to above record levels, with 8 to 15 inches of water contained within this snow. With the ground mainly frozen in the foothills, this water will not be able to soak in and will run off. Water flowing downhill and accumulating in low lying areas may result in localized flooding. Water flowing into creeks and streams will also increase the potential for ice jam development and may result in additional flooding near waterways. Water may accumulate near home foundations increasing the chance of basement flooding. Plugged culverts, ditches, and storm drains may result in water flowing over and possibly eroding roadways in spots. Smaller streams will see the greatest rises, and stream conditions will see rapid changes which could present difficulties for those recreating in the foothills. Unpaved roads may suddenly thaw and become muddy and impassable. While flooding is not imminent, continue to monitor water levels and be prepared to move equipment and livestock out of low lying areas, and away from waterways. Do not drive over flooded roadways, as the roadbed may be washed out. Be especially careful driving at night when water covered roadways are less visible. Recreationists should expect changing conditions and use extra caution near waterways. Stay tuned to the forecast for the latest temperature and precipitation trends, along with any warnings or advisories that may be issued. Please report any flooding to local law enforcement and have them relay the report to the National Weather Service.
